intro: Triosteum erythrocarpum, commonly known as the red-fruited triosteum, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It is a member of the Apiaceae family, characterized by its umbellate inflorescences and aromatic foliage. The plant typically grows in wetlands and along the edges of ponds, thriving in moist, sandy soils. Its fruit, which is red and fleshy, is an important food source for various wildlife species. The leaves are lance-shaped and often have a slightly hairy texture, contributing to its distinctive botanical appearance.
